Award.AbstractNarration:
The 16th International Conference on Permutation Patterns will be held at Dartmouth College in Hanover, New Hampshire, from July 9 to July 13, 2018. The conference will provide a high quality program of speakers in the area of permutation patterns with opportunities for collaboration between junior and senior researchers, as well as between participants from around the world. The conference will feature two plenary one-hour speakers and a number of contributed talks, each thirty minutes long. Researchers will present their new results and there will be time for open discussions to explore unsolved problems in the field. This award supports travel to the conference by students and early career mathematicians from the United States. This conference is part of a series of annual conferences devoted to the area of permutation patterns. Ever since the first conference in 2003, which was hosted by the University of Otago in New Zealand, it has been held every year at different institutions around the world: in North America, Europe, and Australasia.

The conference will feature current research in the area of permutation patterns and its applications. Major themes in the conference include the structural theory of pattern classes, asymptotic behavior of pattern classes, generalized pattern avoidance, packing densities, and algorithmic and decidability problems. Research in the area is influenced by theoretical computer science, and traces its historical origins to the study of sorting machines. Combinatorial interest in permutation patterns focuses on centrally important enumeration and packing problems, for instance the extremal problem to determine how one pattern can be embedded as often as possible in a permutation. The statistics of permutations also enters into the picture, garnering attention from probabilists. The conference is expected to have a wide impact on a variety of different research areas in mathematics and computer science. The conference website is at http://permutationpatterns.com.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Permutation Patterns is the primary annual international conference series in permutation patterns. The 16th occurrence of this conference, Permutation Patterns 2018, took place on July 9-13, 2018, at Dartmouth College in Hanover, New Hampshire. The grant funded partial support for 28 participants, including 4 undergraduate students, 10 graduate students, and 5 early career mathematicians, who are U.S. citizens, permanent residents, or students at US colleges or universities. The 2 plenary speakers, 1 from the US and 1 from the UK, were also funded. The previous meetings of this annual conference have played a pivotal role in fostering and advancing research in permutation patterns.

The conference gave participants an opportunity for collaboration between junior and senior researchers. In addition, newcomers to permutation patterns, including undergraduate students, graduate students, and more established researchers from other areas, gained a broad perspective on the subject from the diversity of research presented at the conference.

The timing and location of PP 2018 (immediately preceding a related larger conference, FPSAC 2018, also at Dartmouth College) has encouraged a higher than usual participation level at Permutation Patterns 2018, while at the same time exposing regular participants of each conference to the state of research in the area of the other.

Permutation patterns researchers work in North America, Europe, East Asia, Middle East and New Zealand, with particularly significant established research groups in the United States, the United Kingdom, France, and New Zealand. The permutation patterns conference has always attracted a large number of graduate and undergraduate students, early career researchers and researchers from primarily undergraduate institutions to present work in this research forum, thus broadening participation in mathematical research. The support provided by this grant made this gathering financially accessible to some participants at the beginning of their research careers.
